data.title: Git gutter indicators doesn't disappear after a commit
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.13.1 (379d2efb5539b09112c793d3d9a413017d736f89, 2017-06-14T18:21:47.485Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 10.0.15063
- Extensions: 

|Extension|Author|Version|
|---|---|---|
|azurenodeessentials|azuresdkteam|0.2.6|
|vscode-eslint|dbaeumer|1.2.11|
|code-runner|formulahendry|0.6.24|
|beautify|HookyQR|1.1.1|
|minify|HookyQR|0.3.0|
|ftp-sync|lukasz-wronski|0.3.3|
|yo|samverschueren|0.9.3|
|vscode-wakatime|WakaTime|1.1.12|
|vsc-jsonsnippets|wmontalvo|0.1.4|;


---

Git gutter indicators doesn't disappear after a commit, you have to change tab and return into it to force a refresh.

Steps to Reproduce:

1.Commit a file.
2.Edit the file, save it and commit all again.
3.Git gutter indicators for the open tab doesn't disappear.

I think it's just a refresh problem.

data.title: Add filtering option on warnings and errors in Problems Output tab

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
Similar to Unity engine console logger..

While we may be able to filter by problems we are not able to filter by errors or warnings instead I am presented with huge list and have to scroll through it! I would like to have option to quickly hide and unhide warnings instead seeing them all in list.. As well as having option to hide and unhide specific errors... Thank you!

data.title: Diff view does not open on click in scm view
data.body:
(Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these)
- VSCode Version: 1.14.0-insider d5e10a589ff68d026ba9cf57485d3004149a9c8a
- OS Version: MacOS Sierra 10.12.5

I haven't found exact steps to reproduce it yet, but it does happen a lot when solving conflicts while rebasing. 

Stack trace from vscode devtools console:

```bash
[Extension Host] oh no
h.logExtensionHostMessage @ extensionHost.ts:320
(anonymous) @ extensionHost.ts:176
emitTwo @ events.js:106
emit @ events.js:191
process.nextTick @ internal/child_process.js:752
_combinedTickCallback @ internal/process/next_tick.js:67
_tickCallback @ internal/process/next_tick.js:98
```

Steps to Reproduce:

1. create git repo
2. create a merge conflict
3. rebase
4. click on files in the scm viewer

**EDIT:** Open the file directly works fine and displays the diff view perfectly.

data.title: Minimap hides after peek definition or find all references
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.13.1 (379d2efb5539b09112c793d3d9a413017d736f89, 2017-06-14T18:21:47.485Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 10.0.14393
- Extensions: 

|Extension|Author|Version|
|---|---|---|
|mssql|ms-mssql|1.0.0|
|csharp|ms-vscode|1.10.0|
|PowerShell|ms-vscode|1.4.0|
|java|redhat|0.6.0|;


---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Enable minimap by placing this in user or workspace settings or both:
```json
{
    "editor.minimap.enabled": true,
    "editor.minimap.renderCharacters": false,
    "editor.minimap.maxColumn": 120
}
```
2. Peek definition and close by clicking on the x button (minimap hides) or by pressing <kbd>Esc</kbd> and then click on the editor, minimap hides then

This gif illustrates this behaviour:

![minimap bug](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/410091/27432920-9d4b863a-5752-11e7-82e1-51a520831bf6.gif)

data.title: Filter settings from no search results link
data.body:
The user is encouraged to check the exclude settings when there are no search
results. Previously this would just open up the settings without any indication
which settings are relevant. This change will update the search filter to show
`files.exclude` and `search.exclude`.

data.title: Add git.autofetchPrune option for enabling --prune
data.body: Implements https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/29217

data.title: [Improvement] Reuse existing split for dual-pane UI features
data.body:
Currently when one uses features such as git diff viewing, or editing settings etc. that themselves use a dual pane view whilst using the editor in a split view already (which I constantly do) VS Code splits the active editor group of the split view (which is already half of the editor window width minus the side bar) to display the two panes (which now end up being quarter width) making any editing inside them nearly impossible until the editor split bar is dragged to widen the active group as much as possible.

What it should be doing is reusing the existing split so that the panes of the dual pane view are assigned to the active and consecutive editor group (i.e. assuming the user has split the editor into three groups, displaying git diff with center group active would cause the diff to be displayed on the center and right group). 

This would greatly improve the usability of such features for users like myself that work mostly or very often with the editor split vertically.

data.title: Revisit smoke test CSS selectors to mimic interactive user behaviour
data.body:
Replace selectors that rely on knowledge where the element is positioned in the DOM.

E.g. avoid CSS selectors that are based on knowledge of the element index in the DOM
`.monaco-list-rows>:nth-child(7)`.

The test should interactively walk down the DOM to find the element needed, similar way human does when working with the view. 

Raised by @joaomoreno

data.title: [Accessibility] Magnifier Focus Tracking Not Working
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.13.1 (379d2efb5539b09112c793d3d9a413017d736f89, 2017-06-14T18:21:47.485Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 6.1.7601
- Extensions: 

|Extension|Author|Version|
|---|---|---|
|java|redhat|0.6.0|;


---

For a screen magnifier user, it is important that text editors notify the accessibility API of caret position changes, so that the magnified view can follow the caret while e.g. writing code. This is not the case in VS Code, regardless of the editor.accessibility setting.

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Launch the Windows screen magnifier by pressing Win and +.
2. In magnifier settings, enable caret tracking if it isn't enabled - "have magnifier follow the text insertion point".
3. Open any file in VS Code.
4. Zoom in to say 4X magnification.
5. Type or use the arrow keys to move the caret off the screen.

What happens? The caret continues moving outside the visible magnified view.
What should happen? The magnified view should follow the caret so that it is never off-screen. For an example of correct behaviour, try the steps above in notepad.

data.title: Disable auto workspace settings
data.body:
Is there an option to disable the automatic creation/save of workspace settings files?

Currently, if you go to File > Preferences > Settings, and if you accidentally click the Workspace Settings tab, it will automatically create a .json file in your working directory. This gets a bit annoying if the project directory is under some sort of source control (git) as it creates a file that you now need to manage (stage, ignore, delete)

I know I can just add this to my .gitignore, but its a bit cumbersome if I have many projects under git control, and I have to add this to every gitignore file

Is there a way to turn this off? Or only create the file on Save so im sure I want the file to exist? (`files.autoSave` is off)

data.title: Inform User if Code use too much RAM / CPU Usage / Startup Time
data.body:
I have seen many threads like CPU usage reached 80% , Code is consuming too much RAM.
and Team members ask users to show the extensions and trying with disabling them.

I think there should be feature in code that should evaluate this performance and usage and should inform use in a message in [announcements](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/27993) with the reasons Code is having trouble or using much RAM. If Code is [intelligent](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/29248) enough then it should inform user that he can disable this extension to improve the Startup.
Or Code Provide APIs in order to let extension authors develop such extension and get stats generated in some HTML page.

Best way would be integration in Extension Manager so user can see rather then providing logs from the console

data.title: Test: Restore UI state for empty windows
data.body:
- [x] win - @jrieken 
- [x] mac - @rebornix 
- [x] linux - @roblourens

Complexity: 5
Refs: https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/207

We always persist and restore all UI state for windows that have a folder opened via the local storage of the browser. For that we used the folder path as identifier to know which UI state to restore. This does however not work if you open an empty folder where we do not have such a folder path for identifying the UI state. The fix was to introduce a new identifier for empty windows to save and load UI state via local storage. This identifier is derived from the backup location for hot exit which we always have to enable hot exit scenarios for any window (folder or empty).

**Basic Functionality**
* verify an empty window restores its UI state (e.g. opened files) between restarts
* verify this also works for window reload
* verify this also restores the windows dimensions and location on screen
* verify the empty window is no longer restored once you
  * open a specific file or folder from the command line
  * open a specific file or folder from the context menu of the OS explorer
  * open up with the "-n" flag to force an empty window
* verify that opening a new window from the running instance always opens it with default UI state (= empty)

**New Setting**

We always had a setting `window.reopenFolders` to control the windows that should be restored (none, one or all). This setting has been renamed to `window.reopenWindows` to better reflect the scenario of restoring empty windows. 

We still want to support the old setting, so verify that
* `window.reopenFolders: none` restores no window (neither empty, nor folders)
* `window.reopenFolders: all` restores all windows (empty and folders) and their size/location on screen

Verify the new setting:
* `window.reopenWindows: none` restores no window (neither empty, nor folders)
* `window.reopenWindows: folders` only restores windows that had folders opened
* * `window.reopenWindows: all` restores all windows (empty and folders) and their size/location on screen

**Hot Exit**

If you have made changes to files in either an empty window or window with folder opened we always restore that window, independent of any setting.
* verify that UI state and window size/location on screen gets restored for all windows that have dirty files independent from the `window.reopenWindows` setting

data.title: Code should display Extensions usage in a summary
data.body:
I have seen many threads like CPU usage reached 80% , Code is consuming too much RAM.
and Team members ask use to show the extensions and trying with disabling them.

For this, i am suggesting a way.
For example a table can be shown that Settings Sync, Python is contributing some amount of CPU or RAM to the total Code process.
Similarly Extension Start up time contributing to code total start up.
If some one debugging the code let say Python, code states will change and alot more information can be given to user.


This should be integrated in Extension Manager so user can see rather then providing logs from the console
